column3: a synthetic data set must be tuned to support a specified setof queries accurately
column4: sacrificing fidelity for other queries. This work considers methods forproducing synthetic data under differential privacy and investigates what makes a set ofqueries “easy” or “hard” to answer. We consider answering sets of linear counting queriesusing the matrix mechanism [15]
column5: a recent differentially-private mechanism that can reduceerror by adding complex correlated noise adapted to a specified workload. Our main result isa novel lower bound on the minimum total error required to simultaneously release answersto a set of workload queries. The bound reveals that the hardness of a query workload is …,CoRR

column1: Pythia: Data dependent differentially private algorithm selection,Ios Kotsogiannis
column4: Gerome Miklau,Abstract Differential privacy has emerged as a preferred standard for ensuring privacy inanalysis tasks on sensitive datasets. Recent algorithms have allowed for significantly lowererror by adapting to properties of the input data. These so-called data-dependent algorithmshave different error rates for different inputs. There is now a complex and growing landscapeof algorithms without a clear winner that can offer low error over all datasets. As a result
column5: thebest possible error rates are not attainable in practice
column6: because the data curator cannotknow which algorithm to select prior to actually running the algorithm. We address thischallenge by proposing a novel meta-algorithm designed to relieve the data curator of theburden of algorithm selection. It works by learning (from non-sensitive data) the associationbetween dataset properties and the best-performing algorithm. The meta-algorithm is …,Proceedings of the 2017 ACM International Conference on Management of Data,2017,8,2

column1: Private Database Synthesis for Outsourced System Evaluation.,Vani Gupta
column3: Neoklis Polyzotis,Abstract. The goal of this paper is to permit secure outsourced system evaluation. Wepropose a method for generating synthetic databases and obfuscating a workload of queriesin order to protect the sensitive information present in the database. The synthetic databaseand workload can be used by a third party to accurately carry out performance tuning
column4: indexselection
column5: or other system evaluation tasks. As a result
column6: an untrusted third party can evaluatewhether a new technology would benefit the data owner without the risk of a privacy breach.Our approach is to employ state-of-the-art privacy mechanisms to compute the sufficientstatistics of a statistical model of the true database. These statistics are safe to release
column7: so athird party can then use them to generate one or more synthetic databases to be used as asurrogate for the true database.,AMW,2011,7,21

column1: Efficient batch query answering under differential privacy,Chao Li
column2: Gerome Miklau,Abstract: Differential privacy is a rigorous privacy condition achieved by randomizing queryanswers. This paper develops efficient algorithms for answering multiple queries underdifferential privacy with low error. We pursue this goal by advancing a recent approachcalled the matrix mechanism
column3: which generalizes standard differentially private mechanisms.This new mechanism works by first answering a different set of queries (a strategy) and theninferring the answers to the desired workload of queries. Although a few strategies areknown to work well on specific workloads
column4: finding the strategy which minimizes error on anarbitrary workload is intractable. We prove a new lower bound on the optimal error of thismechanism
column5: and we propose an efficient algorithm that approaches this bound for a widerange of workloads.,arXiv preprint arXiv:1103.1367,2011,6,18

column1: Boosting the accuracy of differentially-private queries through consistency,Michael Hay
column4: Dan Suciu,ABSTRACT Recent differentially private query mechanisms offer strong privacy guaranteesby adding noise to the query answer. For a single counting query
column5: the technique is simple
column6: accurate
column7: and provides optimal utility. However

column9: the optimal strategy is not apparent
column10: and alternative query strategiescan involve difficult trade-offs in accuracy

column13: we compute the consistent input most likely to have produced the noisy output. Thefinal output is both private and consistent
column15: it is often much more accurate …,CoRR

column1: Self-interested database managers playing the view maintenance game,Hala Mostafa

column6: sequential process where an action taken at a stage affects what happens atlater stages. The contribution of this paper is twofold. First
column7: we formulate the viewmaintenance problem as a sequential game of incomplete information where at every stage
column8: each database manager decides what information to disclose
column9: if any
column10: without knowledge ofthe number or nature of updates at other managers. This allows us to adopt a satisficing …,Proceedings of the 7th international joint conference on Autonomous agents and multiagent systems-Volume 2,2008,6,12

column1: Generating private synthetic databases for untrusted system evaluation,Wentian Lu

column1: View Maintenance With Self-Interested Decision-Makers,Hala Mostafa
column3: Gerome Miklau,Abstract A database view is a dynamic virtual table composed of the result set of a query
column4: often executed over different underlying databases. The view maintenance problemconcerns how a view is refreshed when the data sources are updated. We study the viewmaintenance problem when self-interested database managers from different institutions areinvolved
column5: each concerned about the privacy of its database. We regard view maintenance asan incremental
column6: sequential process where an action taken at a stage affects what happens atlater stages. The contribution of this paper is twofold. First
column7: we formulate the viewmaintenance problem as a sequential game of incomplete information where at every stage
column8: each database manager decides what information to disclose
column9: if any
column10: without knowledge ofthe number or nature of updates at other managers. This allows us to adopt a satisficing …,*,2008,*,10

column1: Principled Evaluation of Differentially Private Algorithms,Michael Hay
column4: Yan Chen
column5: Dan Zhang,Abstract The emergence of differential privacy as a primary standard for privacy protectionhas led to the development of hundreds of algorithms for various data analysis tasks. Thesealgorithms are becoming increasingly complex
column6: and in particular
column7: the performance of manyemerging algorithms is data dependent
column8: meaning the distribution of the noise added toquery answers may change depending on the input data. Theoretical analysis typically onlyconsiders the worst case
column9: making empirical study of average case performance increasinglyimportant. We propose a set of evaluation principles which we argue are essential for soundevaluation. Based on these principles we propose DPBENCH
column10: a novel evaluation frameworkfor standardized evaluation of privacy algorithms. We then apply our benchmark to evaluatealgorithms for answering 1-and 2-dimensional range queries. The result is a thorough …,*,*,*,15

column1: Challenges of Visualizing Differentially Private Data,Dan Zhang
column4: Brendan O’Connor,ABSTRACT Differential privacy has become a primary standard for protecting individual datawhile supporting flexible data analysis. Despite the adaptation of differential privacy to awide variety of applications and tasks
column5: visualizing the output of differentially privatealgorithms has rarely been considered. Visualization is one of the primary means by whichhumans understand and explore an unknown dataset and therefore supporting visualizationis an important goal to advance the practical adoption of differential privacy. In this initialwork on private data visualization we explore key challenges and propose solutionapproaches. We use two-dimensional location data as an example domain
column6: and considerthe challenges of plotting noisy output
column7: the impact of visual artifacts caused by noise
column8: and theproper way to present known uncertainty about private output.,*,*,*,10
